linkTarget.anchoringText: In another hand, Figure 3 illustrates these shear parameters and their distribution across the borehole in three dimensionsal space. These shear moduli are further used to quantify Thomsen's parameters (epsilon, delta, and Gamma) to identify the type of anisotropy. Another parameter used to distinguish between TIV and TIH formations is Gamma.

image-wrap.label: Figure 3
image-wrap.caption: Different parameters and their orientation in space

formatted-caption.caption-text: Different parameters and their orientation in space

linkTarget.anchoringText: All the shear parameteres were estimated across the entire interval and plotted below in Figure 4.

image-wrap.label: Figure 4
image-wrap.caption: Shear parameters (Cij) across the interval along with Thomsen's parameters

formatted-caption.caption-text: Shear parameters (Cij) across the interval along with Thomsen's parameters

linkTarget.anchoringText: The geomechanical earth model or the Mechanical Earth Model (MEM) is a numerical representation of the mechanical properties, vertical stress, pore pressure, horizontal stresses, and rock strength analyzed in a ten-step workflow as showed below on Figure 5.
The Figure 6 below illustrates the workflow used to compute the overburden stress.

image-wrap.label: Figure 7
image-wrap.caption: Mechanical rock properties (PR, Young's Modulus, Thomsen parameters)

formatted-caption.caption-text: Mechanical rock properties (PR, Young's Modulus, Thomsen parameters)

linkTarget.anchoringText: Apart from the vertical stress, the other two far-field stresses are the horizontal stress, as is shown in the Figure 8.

image-wrap.label: Figure 8
image-wrap.caption: Total principal stresses acting on a normal fault

formatted-caption.caption-text: Total principal stresses acting on a normal fault

image-wrap.label: Figure 9
image-wrap.caption: World Stress Map (WSM 2016) showing horizontal stress directions (red lines) based on offset wells and other geologic indicators.

formatted-caption.caption-text: World Stress Map (WSM 2016) showing horizontal stress directions (red lines) based on offset wells and other geologic indicators.

linkTarget.anchoringText: The mud window at a given depth is the range between the maximum & minimum mud weight (MW). Minimum mud weight is defined as the MW below which the wellbore starts generating breakouts. Maximum mud weight is defined as the MW above which the formation starts generation tensile failures and mud loss. Figure 10 below illustrates different mud weight windows responsible for kick, breakouts, losses and fracture. The intention is to always keep the mud weight in the range of safe or stable window highlighted by the green flag in figure 10 below.

image-wrap.label: Figure 10
image-wrap.caption: Mud weight window corresponding to different wellbore events

formatted-caption.caption-text: Mud weight window corresponding to different wellbore events

linkTarget.anchoringText: PP is defined as the pore pressure, UCS is defined as the unconfined compressive strength. All these parameters have been computed during the one-dimensional mechanical earth model (1-D MEM) stage. These parameters are now used in the wellbore stability analysis method to estimate the safe mud weight window to prevent any kind of unwanted wellbore events like kicks, breakouts, washouts, losses and drilling induced fractures as shown below in figure 11.

WBS parameters (mud weight, mudcake coefficient), and MEM data (elastic properties, rock strength, pore pressure, stress) as input and perform WBS analysis with respect to a given depth and sensitivity analysis with respect to a specific input parameter. It represents two polar plots one shear failure minimum mud weight vs borehole orientation and another breakout mud weight vs orientation and two mud weight window plots one mud weight window vs deviation and another mud weight window vs azimuth. Figure 12 below illustrates the sensitivity analysis performed for mud weight over changing azimuth and deviation.

image-wrap.label: Figure 12
image-wrap.caption: WBS Sensitivity analysis for mud weight vs deviation and azimuthal orientation

formatted-caption.caption-text: WBS Sensitivity analysis for mud weight vs deviation and azimuthal orientation

linkTarget.anchoringText: Based on the post-drill MEM-WBS, Pre-drill MEM was obtained based on trajectory in four lateral wells in the same field. Based on these results from wellbore stability analysis and sensitivity studies, recommendations were made for the future drilling of wells. A stable mud weight window was determined based on the pre-drill analysis. Optimum mud weight range of 9.8-10ppg was recommended to minimize the risk of breakout and losses in these lateral wells as shown in the WBS plot (Figure 13).
